questions.text: Below is an image of an MRCP scan. Which of the following options is the most probable diagnosis?  (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Choledocholithiasis

 

The provided MRCP image displays several circular areas with decreased filling within the common bile duct, suggesting the presence of choledocholithiasis.

 

  • Most choledocholithiasis patients presents with obstructive jaundice and biliary colic.
  • Suspecting CBD stones - MRCP (IOC for CBD stone and Klastkin tumor)
  • IOC for small biliary calculi - Endoscopic (ultrasound (EUS)

 

Treatment of CBD stone

 

  • It is usually a slipped stone from GB into CBD (secondary CBD stone)
  • Primary CBD stones - rare, occur due infection of bile duct → seen in low socio economic status → worms infestation → brown pigment stones (due to production of glucoronidase)
  • ERCP – in cases of confirmed CBD stone - diagnostic and therapeutic

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cholecystitis: This condition involves inflammation of the gallbladder, typically caused by gallstones blocking the ducts leading to the gallbladder, but not directly visualized as filling defects in the CBD on MRCP.

 

Option C. Pancreatic duct stricture: A stricture would be seen as a narrowing in the pancreatic duct rather than as filling defects in the bile ducts.

 

Option D. Malignancy: While malignancies can cause biliary obstruction, they usually present as irregular or mass-like obstructions within the bile ducts or surrounding tissues rather than discrete, round filling defects typical of stones.

 

Treatment of CBD Stone:

 

  • Secondary CBD stones are usually stones that have slipped from the gallbladder into the CBD. Treatment typically involves ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography), which is both diagnostic and therapeutic.
  • Primary CBD stones are less common and often associated with chronic infections of the bile duct in areas of low socioeconomic status, leading to brown pigment stones due to the action of bacterial glucuronidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Choledocholithiasis is diagnosed primarily through imaging like MRCP, which reveals stones within the common bile duct as distinct circular filling defects. This condition is a significant cause of biliary obstruction and requires prompt diagnosis and management to prevent complications such as severe biliary colic and obstructive jaundice.

choices.text: Severe illness which is  constant threat to life

questions.text: Which of the following criteria corresponding to ASA grade III? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Severe illness

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. Severe illness: The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System is used to assess and communicate a patient's pre-anesthesia medical co-morbidities. ASA grade III is defined as a patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating. This means the patient has a serious illness, but it does not necessarily pose a constant threat to life, which would correspond to ASA IV.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Mild illness: This corresponds to ASA II, which is defined as a patient with mild systemic disease. It does not reach the severity required for ASA III.

 

Option B. Moderate illness: This is not an official ASA classification term. The closest would be ASA II (mild systemic disease) or ASA III (severe systemic disease).

 

Option C. Severe illness which is a constant threat to life: This corresponds to ASA IV. It describes a patient with severe systemic disease that poses a constant threat to life, not ASA III.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASA grade III corresponds to a patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating.

 

The classification system is as follows:

 

  1. ASA I: A normal healthy patient.
  2. ASA II: A patient with mild systemic disease.
  3. ASA III: A patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating.
  4. ASA IV: A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life.
  5. ASA V: A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation.
  6. ASA VI: A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the following replication cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

The given image shows the life cycle of the herpes simplex virus (HSV).

 

The herpes virus is a linear double-stranded DNA virus with an icosahedral capsid. The envelope has glycoprotein spikes.

 

Steps of HSV replication:

 

  • The virus enters the cell by fusing with the plasma membrane
  • Viral DNA is released from the capsid at the nuclear pore.
  • Transcription of immediate-early genes - alpha-Proteins
  • Transcription of late genes produces y-proteins which consist of viral structural proteins and participate in virion assembly.
  • Viral DNA is cleaved from concatemers and then packaged into capsids.
  • Viral particles which are enveloped, collect in the endoplasmic reticulum
  • They are transported to cell surface by a vesicular movement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) virus is spherical, enveloped virus with an icosahedral shell and a cone-shaped core which encloses the ribonucleoproteins. It consists of two identical single-stranded, RNA copies, with the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is a characteristic feature of retroviruses.

 

HIV virus life cycle.

 

 

Option C. The hepatitis B virus is a DNA virus. It has an outer envelope and an inner nucleocapsid. It contains two linear strands of DNA in a circular configuration. One of the strands (the plus strand is incomplete resulting in partially double stranded and partially single-stranded DNA.

 

 

Option D. Corona viruses: The genome of coronaviruses is made up of positive sense, unsegmented single-stranded RNA. Coronaviruses are enclosed RNA viruses. They feature surface projections in the form of petals. In the cytoplasm, coronavirus nucleocapsids grow and mature by budding into cytoplasmic vesicles. The structure and life cycle of coronaviruses are depicted in the figures below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV), is characterized by steps involving the fusion of the virus with the plasma membrane, nuclear entry, transcription, replication, capsid assembly, glycosylation, and virus release.

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units weekly for three weeks
Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units as single dose
Benzathine penicillin 12-24 million units for 21 days

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of late cardiovascular syphilis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units weekly for three weeks.

 

Late cardiovascular syphilis is a form of tertiary syphilis that typically requires intensive antibiotic treatment to effectively manage the disease. The recommended regimen for treating this condition involves the administration of Benzathine penicillin G at a dose of 2.4 million units administered intramuscularly once a week for a total of three weeks. This regimen is effective because it maintains a therapeutic level of penicillin in the blood over a prolonged period, which is necessary for eradicating the persistent Treponema pallidum bacteria responsible for syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient not able to chew the food and food stuck between cheeks and teeth. Which muscle weakness is associated with this clinical condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buccinator

 

The buccinator muscle, known as the "whistling muscle," is responsible for keeping food between the teeth and preventing it from accumulating in the vestibule (space between teeth and cheeks) during mastication. It helps press the cheek against the teeth, facilitating the proper movement of food in the oral cavity. When it is weak or paralyzed, as can occur in facial nerve (VII) palsy, food gets trapped between the teeth and cheeks because the muscle cannot properly position the food for chewing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Orbicularis oris: Incorrect because this muscle forms the sphincter of the mouth and is responsible for closing and rounding the lips, not for manipulating food during chewing.

 

Option C. Zygomaticus major: Incorrect because this is the "smiling muscle" that draws the angle of the mouth upward and laterally, not involved in keeping food between the teeth during chewing.

 

Option D. Levator labi superioris: Incorrect because this muscle elevates the upper lip and is not primarily involved in keeping food between teeth during mastication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The buccinator muscle, innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII), is essential for keeping food between the teeth during mastication, and its weakness results in food accumulation between cheeks and teeth.

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otto veraguth folds

Allergic rhinitis is a condition characterized by symptoms such as sneezing, nasal congestion, runny nose, and itchy eyes. These symptoms can lead to several physical signs due to chronic inflammation and repetitive actions like rubbing the nose and eyes. However we do not see Otto Veraguth folds in Allergic Rhinitis.

 Also known as Veraguth folds, these are small creases on the upper eyelid and are not related to allergic rhinitis. They are typically associated with individuals suffering from depression, not allergic conditions.

Other Options:

Option A. Allergic Shiners: Commonly seen in allergic rhinitis due to venous congestion under the eyes.

Option B. Allergic Salute: A habitual action in allergic rhinitis leading to a nasal crease.

Option D. Dennis Morgan Lines: Found in chronic allergic conditions due to persistent inflammation and edema, including allergic rhinitis.

Educational Objective: 

Otto Veraguth folds are not associated with allergic rhinitis but are more commonly seen in individuals with depression.

choices.text: Scintigraphy (MIBG) followed by focused neck exploration for parathyroid removal
Perform a DEXA scan, and if normal, will rule out the need for surgery
Assess Creatinine clearance, if > 80 mandates need for surgery

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with findings of hypercalcemia of 12.8 mg% and elevated PTH levels is found to have a 1.5 cm mass below the thyroid. What is the next step? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scintigraphy (MIBG) followed by focused neck exploration for parathyroid removal

 

This is a case of primary hyperparathyroidism due to parathyroid adenoma based on:

 

  • Elevated calcium (12.8 mg%)
  • Elevated PTH
  • Mass below thyroid 

 

Management involves:

 

  1. Localization of adenoma through scintigraphy
  2. Minimally invasive/focused neck exploration
  3. Removal of adenoma
  4. Intraoperative confirmation using Miami criteria (>50% fall in PTH level after 10 minutes of adenoma removal)

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Perform a DEXA scan, and if normal, will rule out the need for surgery: Incorrect. DEXA scan is used to assess bone density but does not alone determine the need for surgery in primary hyperparathyroidism with clear biochemical abnormalities.

 

Option C. Assess Creatinine clearance, if > 80 mandates need for surgery: Incorrect. Creatinine clearance is more relevant in secondary hyperparathyroidism associated with CKD. In primary hyperparathyroidism, the decision for surgery is based on calcium levels, symptoms, and the presence of adenoma.

 

Option D. No surgery, only surveillance needed: Incorrect. With significant hypercalcemia and a visible mass, surveillance alone is inadequate. Surgical removal is indicated.

 

Educational Objective: 


Primary hyperparathyroidism with elevated calcium, elevated PTH, and visible adenoma, the management involves localization through scintigraphy followed by focused surgical removal.

choices.text: Cell cycle will stop at G2
Cell cycle will stop at G1
There will be no effect on cell cycle as RB gene phosphorylation is not needed
The cell cycle progresses and cell divides

questions.text: If the RB gene is hypophosphorylated, which of the following will happen? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cell cycle will stop at G1

 

If the retinoblastoma (RB) gene is hypophosphorylated, then cell cycle will stop at G1.

 

The Rb protein is a tumor suppressor, which plays a pivotal role in the negative control of the cell cycle and in tumor progression. It has been shown that Rb protein (pRb) is responsible for a major G1 checkpoint, blocking S-phase entry and cell growth by binding to and inactivating a transcription factor (E2F). The phosphorylation of RB results in the release of E2F activating gene transcription and cell-cycle progression occurs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cell cycle will stop at G2: This is incorrect because the Rb protein specifically regulates the G1 to S phase transition, not the G2 phase.

 

Option C. There will be no effect on cell cycle as RB gene phosphorylation is not needed: This is incorrect. The phosphorylation state of the Rb protein is crucial for its function in regulating the cell cycle. Hypophosphorylated Rb actively suppresses cell cycle progression at G1.

 

Option D. The cell cycle progresses and cell divides: This is incorrect because the hypophosphorylated form of Rb prevents the cell from progressing past the G1 phase, thereby halting cell division.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hypophosphorylated state of the Rb protein prevents the cell cycle from progressing past the G1 phase by binding to and inactivating E2F, thereby acting as a crucial checkpoint in preventing uncontrolled cell proliferation.

questions.text: The wrong statement regarding the levator ani muscle is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Attached to pelvic brim

 

Explanation:

 

The levator ani is not attached to the pelvic brim. Instead, it originates from the posterior surface of the body of the pubis, the obturator fascia, and the ischial spine. It then inserts into the coccyx, anococcygeal ligament, and walls of the prostate or vagina, rectum, and anal canal. The incorrect notion about its attachment to the pelvic brim is a common misconception.

 

  • Insertion :- The coccyx and the anococcygeal raphe or ligament.
  • Nerve supply:- The branches of the anterior rami of sacral nerves S3 and S4 and the perineal branch of the pudendal nerve.
  • Supports and raises the pelvic floor.
  •  Consists of the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supports pelvic viscera: This statement is correct. The levator ani, along with other pelvic floor muscles, forms a supportive sling for the pelvic organs such as the bladder, uterus (in females), and rectum. This muscular support is essential for maintaining continence and facilitating functions such as micturition and defecation.

 

Option B. Converge downwards and medially: This statement is also correct. The fibers of the levator ani muscles, especially from the pubococcygeus, tend to converge towards the midline and run in a downward direction. This orientation provides the necessary support to the pelvic organs and creates a muscular barrier between the pelvic cavity and the perineum.

 

Option C. Consists of iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus: This statement is partially true. The levator ani is made up of three parts: the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus. All three parts contribute to the function and support provided by the levator ani. Thus, while the statement includes two components of the levator ani, it omits the puborectalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic brim is not connected to the levator ani muscle. It originates from the ischial spine, levator ani's arcus tendinous (a thickened section of the obturator fascia, and the pubic body.

choices.text: Start ART if CD4 <200
Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks
Start ATT and ART simultaneously

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. His sputum sample showed acid-fast bacilli. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks


In HIV patients with tuberculosis (TB), it is crucial to start antitubercular therapy (ATT) first to reduce the mycobacterial load before initiating antiretroviral therapy (ART). This approach helps to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS), a life-threatening condition due to massive cytokine response triggered by a rapid increase in CD4 count., which can occur if ART is started too early. The general recommendation is to start ART by 2 weeks -2 months, after ATT initiation.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Starting ART only if CD4 <200: does not address the immediate need for TB treatment.

 

Option B. Starting ART before ATT: can lead to IRIS.

 

Option D. Starting both therapies simultaneously:  increases the risk of IRIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV patients with TB, start ATT first and then initiate ART after 2 weeks-2 months duration.

questions.text: In the motor homunculus, which of the following has maximum representation? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Precision of movements

 

Precision of movements has maximum representation in the motor homunculus.

 

In the sensory homunculus, the relative sizes of the cortical areas is proportional to the use of the part, the number of specialized sensory receptors and precision required by respective peripheral area of the body.

 

Some body parts like lips are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex followed by the face and thumb while the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by relatively small areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low control and skilled movements: Incorrect, as areas requiring low control do not have extensive cortical representation.

 

Option B. More muscle fibres are present: Incorrect, as the size of representation in the motor homunculus is not based on the number of muscle fibers, but rather on the precision and complexity of movements.

 

Option D. Intensity of perception: Incorrect, as intensity of perception is related to sensory input and the sensory homunculus, not the motor homunculus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The motor homunculus has maximum representation for body parts requiring precision of movements, reflecting the complexity and intricacy needed for fine motor control.

questions.text: Counter force brace is used for:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tennis elbow

 

TENNIS ELBOW OR LATERAL EPICONDYLITIS

 

  • Any occupation that requires repeated/sustained wrist extension or repeated pinching/grasping can result in lateral epicondylitis; the condition is, therefore, not limited to sports-related (i.e., one-handed tennis back hand) injuries.
  • Classically, this is tendonitis of the extensor carpi radialis brevis (common extensor origin) tendon at the lateral humeral epicondyle, but can affect the extensor carpi radialis longus at the supracondylar line.

 

 

  • It may result in small tears, fibrocartilaginous metaplasia, microscopic calcification and painful vascular reaction in tendon fibers close to lateral epicondyle (degenerative changes with angiofibroblastic proliferation).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Localized tenderness at or just below lateral epicondyle.
    • Pain can be reproduced by passively stretching the extensor radialis brevis. This is done by extending the elbow, pronating the forearm and then passively flexing the wrist or active extension of wrist against resistance can produce pain (Cozen’s test).

 

 

  • Pain with resisted extension (as seen in the Chair test) or with activities such as wrist dorsiflexion or gripping activities is typically reported by the patient.
     

  • Management:
    • Usual treatment includes work modification to minimize contributing activities with the focus on a better anthropomorphic match between the user and their work environment in contrast to a one-size-fits-all design strategy.
    • Acute pain can be treated with anti-inflammatories, cold pack massage over the extensor origin, rest, a wrist extensor strengthening regimen, or use of a counterforce (“tennis elbow”) brace.
    • The proposed mechanism for this brace is the dissipation of the forces away from the injured tissue to the surrounding noninjured area. 
    • This type of brace can be both a rehabilitative and a functional orthosis.

 

 

  • Chronic lateral epicondylitis treatment strategies in the context of employment are more controversial.
     

  • Some common treatments include steroid injection, platelet rich plasma, dry needling/trigger point injections, physical therapy to include isometric and concentric exercises, and stretches.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Wrist drop. For wrist drop due to radial nerve palsy, a dynamic cock-up splint is given.

 

 

Option C. Foot drop. For foot drop, an AFO or ankle-foot orthosis or leaf brace is given.

 

 

Option D. Ankle sprain. For ankle sprain, an adjustable ankle brace is given.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Counter force brace is used for the rehabilitation of tennis elbow.
  • This brace dissipates the forces away from the injured tissue to the surrounding non-injured area.

choices.text: Regeneration is limited to the limbus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about corneal epithelium? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bowman's membrane regenerates.

 

The false statement about the corneal epithelium is B, stating that "Bowman's membrane regenerates." This is incorrect as Bowman's membrane is an acellular layer composed of collagen fibers and, once damaged, does not regenerate. The other statements regarding the corneal epithelium are true and align with the anatomical and functional characteristics of the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Regeneration is limited to the limbus: This is true as limbal stem cells are key to the regeneration of the corneal epithelium.

 

Option C. Lined by stratified squamous epithelium: True, this describes the specific cell type forming the corneal epithelium.

 

Option D. Apical cells have microvilli: Also true, the microvilli increase the surface area for better adhesion of the tear film, enhancing eye lubrication and protection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is an AR murmur likely to be heard? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ventricular diastole


Aortic regurgitation (AR) murmurs are classic early diastolic murmurs heard during ventricular diastole, when blood flows back into the left ventricle from the aorta.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Ventricular ejection: Associated with systolic murmurs.
 

Option B. Throughout cardiac cycle: Associated with continuous murmurs, like in PDA.
 

Option C. Isovolumetric contraction: Not typically associated with murmurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic regurgitation murmurs are heard during ventricular diastole

questions.text:
A couple already has 3 children and has been trying for another one for the last 1 year. However, the husband is diagnosed with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Which of the following is/are true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Low FSH, low LH
  2. High FSH, low LH
  3. Oligospermia
  4. Low prolactin
  5. Low testosterone
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 5

 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is a condition where there is decreased production of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland, leading to decreased stimulation of the testes and consequent reduced production of sex hormones such as testosterone. This results in:

 

1. Low FSH, low LH: In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, both follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) are low due to inadequate stimulation from the pituitary gland.

 

3. Oligospermia: Reduced levels of FSH and LH lead to decreased stimulation of the testes, which can result in reduced sperm production and oligospermia (low sperm count).

 

5. Low testosterone: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leads to reduced levels of testosterone because the testes are not adequately stimulated by FSH and LH.

 

The following are not true for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism:

 

2. High FSH, low LH: This pattern is more characteristic of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (primary testicular failure) rather than hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

4. Low prolactin: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is typically associated with normal or high levels of prolactin if there is an underlying pituitary issue. Low prolactin is not a characteristic feature of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, both FSH and LH levels are low, testosterone levels are low, and oligospermia is often present.

 

Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis is due to which property of the codon?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Degeneracy

 

  • The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code. Degeneracy means that multiple codons can code for the same amino acid. The third position of the codon (the wobble position) is less constrained and allows for some variation in the base pairing, which accommodates the degeneracy in the genetic code.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ambiguity: Ambiguity is not a property of the codon but rather a state of uncertainty or multiple interpretations. In the genetic code, codons are specific and not ambiguous in their assignment to amino acids.

 

Option C. Universality: Universality refers to the fact that the genetic code is nearly identical in all living organisms. While universality is an important property of the genetic code, it is not directly related to the wobble hypothesis.

 

Option D. Commaless: "Commaless" is not a recognized property related to the codon or the wobble hypothesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code, allowing multiple codons to code for the same amino acid, with variation in the third (wobble) position of the codon.

 

Wobble bases

 

3rd base of the codon on mRNA and 1st base of anticodon on tRNA in 5’ to 3’ direction are wobble positions.

 

 

Wobble hypothesis says that for binding between bases present in these positions, some imprecision is allowed. i.e. one base in anticodon can bind with various bases of codon. This is also called as degeneracy of codon i.e. There is more than one codon for one amino acid. So, Wobble hypothesis is due to degeneracy of codons.

questions.text: Identify the incision made and marked is the image: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gibson abernathy

 

  • The Gibson incision is correct in this scenario, assuming the surgical mark and procedure are aimed at accessing structures in the lower quadrant of the abdomen or the pelvis. This incision provides the necessary exposure while minimizing damage to the muscular and nerve structures

 

This is a type of oblique incision made along the line of the inguinal ligament. It is primarily used for procedures involving the lower ureter, pelvic kidney, or bladder surgery. It provides excellent exposure to the lower abdomen and pelvic areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robson : This is also known as the "classic gridiron" incision. It's a muscle-splitting incision used primarily for accessing the appendix during an appendectomy. It runs obliquely in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.

 

Option B. Battle: Less commonly referenced, this incision isn't widely recognized in standard surgical texts under this name. It may refer to a specialized or less commonly used approach.

 

Option D. Kocher: This incision is typically used for biliary surgery. It is a subcostal incision made parallel to the costal margin, usually on the right side, to provide access to the gallbladder and biliary tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gibson Incision is a type of oblique incision made along the line of the inguinal ligament. It is primarily used for procedures involving the lower ureter, pelvic kidney, or bladder surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT involved in renal auto-regulation?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Renal sympathetic system fires

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure very widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

The sympathetic nervous system can also influence renal blood flow, but its role is primarily to modulate GFR in response to systemic conditions rather than as part of the intrinsic autoregulatory mechanisms. Therefore, renal sympathetic system firing is not considered a key component of renal autoregulation.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

 

  1. Myogenic response - mechanism that contributes to the maintenance of a relatively constant renal blood flow and GFR
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback via macula densa. Renin-angiotensin system also plays a role.

 

 

 

 

Macula densa feedback mechanism for autoregulation of glomerular hydrostatic pressure and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) during decreased renal arterial pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubuloglomerular feedback: Incorrect. Tubuloglomerular feedback is a key component of renal autoregulation.

 

Option B. Myogenic reflex: Incorrect. The myogenic reflex is a crucial mechanism in renal autoregulation.The myogenic reflex helps regulate GFR by directly responding to changes in blood pressure (BP) within the afferent arteriole, which supplies blood to the glomerulus. When BP  increases, the afferent arteriole smooth muscle stretches, triggering a contraction (vasoconstriction) that reduces blood flow into the glomerulus, thus decreasing GFR.

 

Option C. Renin-angiotensin system: Incorrect. The renin-angiotensin system supports renal autoregulation, particularly in adjusting the efferent arteriolar resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal autoregulation primarily involves the myogenic response and tubuloglomerular feedback mechanisms to maintain stable GFR. The renal sympathetic system, while involved in renal blood flow regulation, is not part of intrinsic autoregulation mechanisms.

questions.text: What does the provided formula correspond to? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Standard deviation

 

  • The formula given represents the standard deviation, which measures the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of values.
  • It is the square root of the variance, where the variance is the average of the squared differences from the mean.
  • Standard deviation: This is the deviation of each value from the standard value (mean). It provides insight into the spread of the data points around the mean.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variance = (Standard deviation)2. It represents the average of the squared deviations from the mean.

 

Option C. Mean is obtained as the sum of all values divided by the number of values. It is not affected by extreme values.

 

Option D. Median is the middle most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Standard deviation is the deviation of each value from the standard value [Mean].

questions.text: All of the following conditions are caused by high-risk strains of Human Papilloma virus except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papillomatosis

 

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis is not caused by high-risk HPV strains but by low-risk HPV strains (6 and 11).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical carcinoma: Caused by high-risk HPV strains, particularly HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. Anal carcinoma: Also associated with high-risk HPV strains, including HPV 16.

 

Option C. Oropharyngeal carcinoma: Linked to high-risk HPV strains, notably HPV 16.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis is caused by low-risk HPV strains (6 and 11) and not by the high-risk strains associated with cancers such as cervical, anal, and oropharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 563

choices.text: Change in pH other than isoelectric pH

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for protein precipitation? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Change in pH other than isoelectric pH

 

Protein precipitation is typically achieved using methods like alcohol, acetone, or trichloroacetic acid, or by changing the pH to the protein's isoelectric point (pI).

 

Isoelectric pH, protein’s net charge is zero, known as Zwitterion. This structure is insoluble, so precipitates out

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heavy metals: Heavy metals are not typically used for protein precipitation. They are more commonly associated with toxicity and contamination in biological samples rather than being used as precipitants.

 

Option B. Alcohol & acetone: Alcohol and acetone are frequently used for protein precipitation. They are added to protein solutions to denature proteins, causing them to precipitate out of the solution.

 

Option D. Trichloroacetic acid: Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is commonly used for protein precipitation. It is an acidic compound that can effectively precipitate proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isoelectric pH, protein’s net charge is zero, known as Zwitterion. This structure is insoluble, so precipitates out. At acidic pH, protein has positive charge.  At alkaline pH, protein has negative charge. 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 19

questions.text: Defect at the level of the optic chiasma will result in which of the following visual field defects? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitemporal hemianopia

 

Lesion at the level of the optic chiasma causes bitemporal hemianopia.

 

Nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma. Hence, the lesion at this level produces bitemporal hemianopia.

 

 

Common causes of the central chiasmal lesion are as follows:

 

  • Suprasellar aneurysms
  • Tumors of the pituitary gland
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Suprasellar meningioma
  • Glioma of the third ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central Scotoma - This refers to a loss of vision in the central visual field and is typically associated with diseases affecting the macula or the optic nerve, not lesions at the chiasm.

 

Option B. Bilateral Hemianopia - This would involve a loss of vision in the same half of the visual field of each eye (either left or right), which generally occurs with lesions affecting the optic tract or occipital lobe, not the chiasm.

 

Option C. Binasal Hemianopia - This visual field defect involves loss of vision in the nasal halves (the sides closest to the nose) of both eyes, which is uncommon and would more likely result from unusual patterns of optic nerve damage rather than a central chiasmal lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitemporal hemianopia is a classic sign of a lesion at the optic chiasm, often caused by conditions like pituitary tumors or chiasmal compression. This key symptom helps in diagnosing issues that may require urgent intervention to prevent further neurological damage.

questions.text: Based on the ECG given below, which of the following drugs is NOT used in the management of the condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine

 

The ECG shows a case of atrial fibrillation, characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm and the absence of distinct P waves. Instead, there are fibrillatory waves that can be seen in the baseline. Atrial fibrillation is a common type of irregular heart rhythm where the atria beat chaotically and irregularly.

 

Adenosine is not used in the management of atrial fibrillation. It is primarily indicated for the treatment of regular narrow complex tachycardias, such as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Adenosine works by temporarily blocking the atrioventricular (AV) node, which can help reset the heart rhythm in cases of regular tachycardias. However, in irregular rhythms like atrial fibrillation, adenosine is contraindicated because it can induce atrial fibrillation or exacerbate the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker used in the management of atrial fibrillation. It helps control the heart rate by slowing down the conduction through the AV node.

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication used for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation. It can help to convert atrial fibrillation to a normal sinus rhythm and maintain it.

 

Option D. Diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to control the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation by slowing conduction through the AV node.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenosine should not be used in the management of atrial fibrillation due to its potential to induce or worsen the condition.

questions.text: Insulin independent absorption occurs in all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adipose

 

Glucose uptake in adipose tissue is insulin-dependent, primarily using GLUT4 transporters activated by insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC: Red Blood Cells utilize GLUT1 transporters for glucose absorption, which is insulin-independent and crucial for their energy needs.

 

Option C. Pancreas: While the pancreas plays a role in insulin production, its glucose absorption is not predominantly insulin-independent.

 

Option D. Brain: The brain absorbs glucose independently of insulin, using GLUT3 transporters, essential for its constant energy requirements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose uptake in adipose tissue is insulin-dependent, while RBCs, pancreas, and brain utilize insulin-independent mechanisms for glucose absorption.

choices.text: Carcinoid tumor of the ovary
Theca cell tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is a virilizing ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arrhenoblastoma

 

Arrhenoblastoma, also known as Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, is a virilizing ovarian tumor that can produce androgens leading to masculinization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brenner tumor: Brenner tumors are epithelial ovarian cancer

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor of the ovary: Carcinoid tumors is a germ cell tumor, primarily produce serotonin and do not typically cause virilization.

 

Option D. Theca cell tumor: Theca cell tumors are sex xord tumours and can produce estrogen, not androgens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arrhenoblastoma is a virilizing ovarian tumor known for its androgen production, often leading to masculinizing symptoms in females.

choices.text: Nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation of hip.
Vascular injury is more common in anterior hip dislocation.
Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior.
In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation.

questions.text: Mark incorrect option: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nerve injury more common in anterior dislocation of hip.

 

 

 

  • “Nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation of hip” – this statement is incorrect. 
  • In posterior hip dislocations, the sciatic nerve is at significant risk of injury. This is the most common nerve injury associated with hip dislocations.
  • In anterior hip dislocations, the femoral nerve or obturator nerve can be injured, but these are generally less common than sciatic nerve injury in posterior dislocations.
  • Therefore, stating nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation is false as it is more common in posterior dislocations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vascular injury more common in anterior hip dislocation. This statement is correct. This is so because the femoral vessels are in close proximity to the hip joint anteriorly, so there are more chances of vascular injury to occur from anterior hip dislocation. Major vascular injuries are rare in both anterior and posterior dislocations. 

 

Option C. Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior. This statement is correct. The incidence of posterior dislocation of hip is around 90%. This is because of the greater strength of anterior ligaments than the posterior ones. 

 

Option D. In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation. This statement is true. The position of the limb when a patient presents with posterior hip dislocation is of Flexion, Adduction and Internal Rotation i.e., FADIR while in anterior dislocation, it is FABER i.e., Flexion, Abduction and External Rotation. 

 

 

FADIR in posterior hip dislocation

 

Educational Objective:

 

In anterior dislocation of hip, vascular injuries are more common whereas in posterior dislocation, nerve injury (particularly sciatic nerve) is more common.

choices.text: Delayed diastolic depolarization
Increase in plateau
Decrease in preload
Increase in afterload

questions.text: What is the mechanism by which acetylcholine causes a decrease in the heart rate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Delayed diastolic depolarization

 

Acetylcholine decreases heart rate by acting on muscarinic M2 receptors present in the sinoatrial (SA) node of the heart. The key mechanism involves:

 

  • Activation of M2 Receptors: When acetylcholine binds to M2 receptors, it activates a G-protein coupled pathway.
  • Opening of Potassium Channels: This leads to the opening of specific potassium channels (GIRK channels) resulting in an increased efflux of potassium ions from the SA node cells.
  • Hyperpolarization: The efflux of potassium causes hyperpolarization of the cell membrane, making it more negative.
  • Delayed Diastolic Depolarization: This hyperpolarization delays the diastolic depolarization phase, slowing the rate at which the SA node reaches the threshold potential to initiate the next action potential.
  • Result: The overall effect is a reduction in the heart rate (negative chronotropy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in Plateau:

 

  • Mechanism: An increase in the plateau phase would generally refer to the action of calcium channels during the action potential of myocardial cells, not the SA node. This mechanism is more related to the contractile cells rather than pacemaker cells.
  • Effect: This does not directly influence heart rate but can affect the force of contraction.

 

Option C. Decrease in Preload:

 

  • Mechanism: Preload refers to the end-diastolic volume in the ventricles. While changes in preload can influence stroke volume and cardiac output, they are not directly related to the rate control mechanisms mediated by acetylcholine.

 

Option D. Increase in Afterload:

 

  • Mechanism: Afterload refers to the resistance the heart must pump against, primarily influenced by systemic vascular resistance. This is not directly influenced by acetylcholine's action on the SA node and does not explain the decrease in heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The acetylcholine acts on the M2 receptor present on the SA node. This opens a special set of potassium channels causing an efflux of potassium (kAch) which hyperpolarizes the SA node. This leads to delayed depolarization of the SA node during ventricular diastole, thus leading to a slow heart rate.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment according to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey 2015-19? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Untreated cataract

 

According to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey (2015-19), the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment (MSVI) is untreated cataract.

 

MSVI is defined as visual acuity of <6/18 to 3/60 in the better eye, even with available correction. Cataracts are a leading cause of vision loss globally, particularly in individuals over the age of 50 years, due to the clouding of the lens that can occur with aging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Refractive error: Refractive errors are a common cause of visual impairment but are more prevalent in patients under 49 years and are generally correctable with glasses or other corrective measures.

 

Option C. Glaucoma: Glaucoma, although a significant cause of visual impairment, accounts for a smaller proportion of cases compared to cataracts, especially in older populations.

 

Option D. Diabetic retinopathy: Diabetic retinopathy can lead to visual impairment, but its prevalence as a cause of moderate-severe visual impairment is lower compared to cataracts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Untreated cataracts are the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment in individuals over the age of 50, according to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey 2015-19. Cataracts are a treatable cause of blindness and emphasize the need for timely surgical intervention to restore vision.

choices.text: Pap smear + HPV DNA every 5 yearly

questions.text: Dr. Savita is posted in a low-resource hospital setting. She explains to a patient about risk factors of cervical cancer, including HPV. Which of the following would be appropriate for cervical cancer screening? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pap smear alone every 3 yearly

 

In a low-resource hospital setting, Pap smear alone every 3 years is the most appropriate screening method for cervical cancer. The screening should begin at age 21 years (some guidelines recommend 25 years). While HPV testing has become the method of choice in many updated guidelines, in resource-limited settings, Pap smear remains the primary screening tool due to its cost-effectiveness and established infrastructure.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Pap smear alone every 5 yearly: Incorrect because the recommended interval for Pap smear screening is 3 years, not 5 years. Five-yearly screening is appropriate for HPV testing or co-testing.

 

Option B. Pap smear + HPV DNA every 5 yearly: Incorrect because while co-testing is an acceptable method, it increases costs and is not the method of choice in low-resource settings. This option would unnecessarily increase the financial burden.

 

Option D. Pap smear in high-risk individuals: Incorrect because cervical cancer screening should be done in all eligible women, not just high-risk individuals. Universal screening is essential for effective prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In low-resource settings, cervical cancer screening should be done using Pap smear alone every 3 years, starting from age 21 years.

questions.text: Which of the following best represents the primary concern addressed by the POCSO Act? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Child sexual abuse

 

  • The POCSO Act (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act) 2012 is designed to protect children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse and exploitation.
  • It includes provisions for punishment of various offenses such as penetrative sexual assault, aggravated penetrative sexual assault, sexual assault, aggravated sexual assault, sexual harassment, and the use of children for pornography.
  • The act ensures stringent punishment for offenders to provide a safe and secure environment for children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Women empowerment: Incorrect. The POCSO Act is focused on protecting children from sexual offenses, not specifically on women empowerment.

 

Option B. Human trafficking: Incorrect. While important, human trafficking is not the primary focus of the POCSO Act.

 

Option C. Juvenile delinquency: Incorrect. The act deals with protecting children from sexual offenses, not addressing juvenile delinquency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

POCSO Act (Prevention of Children from Sexual Offences Act) 2012

 

  • Child definition: Any person less than 18 years of age
  • Includes: Sexual abuses and pornography
  • Punishments under the act:

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

Let's match the descriptions to the terms:

 

A. Depression : "Difficult to diagnose due to the shell of physician’s pride" would suggest that physicians might not show or express their symptoms due to professional pride. So, A matches with 3.

 

B. Suicide : "Women physicians, substance abuse, relationship troubles" could be potential risk factors or associated factors. So, B matches with 4.

 

C. Burnout : "State of emotional and physical exhaustion caused by prolonged stress, relieved after relaxation" perfectly describes burnout. So, C matches with 2.

 

D. Overthinking : "The feeling goes away as soon as you leave the hospital" does not clearly correlate with overthinking, but given the other matches, this seems the closest fit. So, D matches with 1.

 

So, the correct matching would be:

 

A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 447, 764.

choices.text: Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly
Genital and oral painful ulcers
Glomerulonephritis and heart failure
Joint pains with nodules on skin

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with a history of backache and polyarthralgia. Immunofluorescence (IF) findings reveal a nucleolar pattern. Which of the following clinical features is most consistent with her condition? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly

 

The nucleolar pattern observed on immunofluorescence (IF) suggests systemic sclerosis, also known as sclerodactyly. This autoimmune condition often presents with Raynaud phenomenon and thickening of the skin, particularly affecting the fingers and hands (sclerodactyly). The nucleolar pattern reflects antibodies to RNA, commonly seen in sclerodactyly and other forms of systemic sclerosis. In limited systemic sclerosis, patients may develop a constellation of symptoms including Calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia (CREST syndrome).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Genital and oral painful ulcers: These are characteristic of Behçet's disease, an inflammatory disorder that does not typically present with a nucleolar pattern on IF.

 

Option C. Glomerulonephritis and heart failure: These symptoms suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or another vasculitis, which do not typically display a nucleolar pattern but rather a diffuse or speckled pattern on IF.

 

Option D. Joint pains with nodules on skin: This presentation is more typical of rheumatoid arthritis, which is associated with rheumatoid nodules and does not usually present with a nucleolar IF pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nucleolar pattern on immunofluorescence is most commonly associated with systemic sclerosis (sclerodactyly) and is often accompanied by features such as Raynaud phenomenon and skin thickening.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most severe manifestation of CKD? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia 

 

Hyperkalemia, characterized by elevated potassium levels in the blood, is particularly dangerous in CKD due to its direct impact on cardiac function. High potassium levels can disrupt normal heart rhythms, potentially leading to life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased GFR: While it indicates the progression of CKD and reduced kidney function, it does not pose immediate life-threatening risks like hyperkalemia.

 

Option B. Increased creatinine: Indicates kidney dysfunction but is a marker rather than a direct cause of severe clinical consequences.

 

Option D. Proteinuria: Signifies kidney damage; however, it is more of a prognostic indicator rather than an acute life-threatening condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia in CKD patients is a critical condition that requires immediate medical attention due to its potential to cause fatal cardiac disturbances. Always prioritize the management of hyperkalemia in CKD patients to prevent cardiac complications.

questions.text: Nerve fibre least susceptible to local anaesthetic is? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. C fibres

 

Explanation:

 

The nerve fibre least susceptible to local anaesthetic is type C. Local anaesthetics work by blocking sodium channels, which prevents the initiation and propagation of action potentials in nerves. The effectiveness of local anaesthetics depends on the diameter and myelination of the nerve fibres.

 

Type C fibres are unmyelinated and have the smallest diameter, making them the least susceptible to local anaesthetics. This means they require a higher concentration of the anaesthetic to achieve the same level of blockade as larger, myelinated fibres.

 

The order of susceptibility of nerve fibres to local anaesthetics is:

 

B > A-d > A-g > A-b > A-a > C

 

  • Nerve fibres most susceptible to local anesthetic: B fibres

  • Nerve fibres most resistant to local anesthetic: C fibres

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A-delta: These are myelinated fibres with a small diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to C fibres but less susceptible than larger, myelinated fibres like A-beta and A-alpha.

 

Option B. A-gamma: These are myelinated fibres with a moderate diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to A-delta fibres but less susceptible than A-beta and A-alpha fibres.

 

Option C. A-beta: These are myelinated fibres with a larger diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to A-delta and A-gamma fibres.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Type C nerve fibres are the least susceptible to local anaesthetics due to their small diameter and lack of myelination.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 1416-1417

choices.text: Remove placenta and reposition the uterus
Put uterus inside without removing the placenta
Shift to OT and insert the uterus back

questions.text: A patient has just delivered a full-term baby and developed uterine inversion with the placenta still attached. What is the immediate next step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Put uterus inside without removing the placenta

 

Immediate management of uterine inversion involves repositioning the uterus before removing the placenta to prevent severe bleeding and shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to massive hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Shift to OT and insert the uterus back: Immediate manual repositioning is crucial before shifting to an operating theatre.

 

Option D. Start Oxytocin: Oxytocin is used after the uterus is repositioned to encourage contraction, not before.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of uterine inversion, the uterus should be repositioned with the placenta still attached to avoid significant bleeding, followed by medical management for uterine contraction.

questions.text: Which among the following organs has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kidney

 

The arteriovenous oxygen difference (A-V O2 difference) is a measure of the amount of oxygen extracted by the tissues from the blood. The greater the oxygen utilization by the tissues, the larger the A-V O2 difference.

 

  • Kidney: The kidney has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference. This is because the primary function of the kidneys is to filter large volumes of blood through the glomeruli rather than to metabolize oxygen extensively. As a result, the oxygen extracted by the renal tissues is relatively low compared to the amount of blood flow, resulting in a low A-V O2 difference.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain: The brain has a higher arteriovenous oxygen difference due to its significant metabolic activity and oxygen consumption to support its functions. The brain requires a constant and substantial supply of oxygen for neuronal activity, resulting in a higher A-V O2 difference compared to the kidney.

 

Option C. Skin: The skin also has a relatively low oxygen consumption compared to organs like the brain and liver, but its arteriovenous oxygen difference is still higher than that of the kidney. The skin is primarily involved in protective functions and thermoregulation, requiring less oxygen.

 

Option D. Liver: The liver has a moderate to high arteriovenous oxygen difference due to its metabolic functions, including detoxification, synthesis of proteins, and other vital activities that require substantial oxygen consumption. The liver's metabolic demands make its A-V O2 difference higher than that of the kidney.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The kidney has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference among the given organs due to its primary function of blood filtration, which requires relatively low oxygen extraction. This results in a low A-V O2 difference compared to organs like the brain and liver that have higher metabolic and oxygen consumption demands.

questions.text: Which of the following is a centrally acting opioid antitussive?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Levopropoxyphene

 

  • Propoxyphene has two isomers: Levopropoxyphene and Dextropropoxyphene. Levopropoxyphene is a centrally acting opioid antitussive. It is an opioid derivative that acts centrally as a strong and partial µ receptor agonist and helps to reduce the cough reflex. It has no analgesic property but can cause some degree of sedation. Please note that the other isomer dextropropoxyphene is mainly used as an analgesic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ambroxol is derived from bromhexine. It increases mucociliary clearance, thereby providing relief in productive cough. Thus it is primarily used as a mucolytic (not anti-tussive). Further it is not an opioid.

 

Option B. Diphenoxylate or Loperamide is indicated for non-infective diarrhea. These are not used as anti-tussive.

 

Option D. Levorphanol is a synthetic opioid which is chiefly used in the management of moderate to severe pain. It also have some anti-tussive properties similar to codeine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levopropoxyphene is a centrally acting opioid specifically used for its antitussive properties. While levorphanol is also an opioid with antitussive effects, it is more commonly used for pain relief. Levopropoxyphene's primary indication as an antitussive makes it the most appropriate choice among the given options.

choices.text: TACE is used for multinodular lesions
Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm
The incidence of HCC is increasing
NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC

questions.text: Identify the false statement out of the following: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm

 

Lenvatinib is used to treat advanced stages of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Treatment of lesions less than 3 cm is wide excision or liver transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TACE is used for multinodular lesions: True. TACE (Transarterial chemoembolization) combined with other treatments is used for unresectable multiple nodular and massive HCC, especially when a single nodular diameter is greater than 5 cm (intermediate or advanced HCC).

 

Option C. The incidence of HCC is increasing: True. The incidence of HCC is increasing worldwide due to the increase in HCV and HBV infections, along with lifestyle disorders like obesity.

 

Option D. NASH (Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis) and NAFLD (Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease) are risk factors for HCC: True. Obesity is associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NALD), which progresses to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) causing cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Thus, NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Barcelona-Clinic-Liver Cancer (BCLC) Classification is the commonly used staging system for HCC.
  • Very early HCC is treated by ablation, early HCC with a single nodule is resected, and when there are multiple nodules over 3 cm, ablation or transplantation are considered.
  • Intermediate stage HCC is treated by chemoembolization, and TACE (Trans-arterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions.
  • Advanced stages of the disease with macrovascular invasion are treated with systemic therapies. Lenvatinib and sorafenib are first-line drugs.
  • Supportive care is given at the terminal stage of the disease.

questions.text: Structure which is related deep to marked structure? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stem of lateral sulcus

 

The marked structure in the image is the pterion, which is an H-shaped area on the lateral side of the skull where four bones meet (frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid). The central part of the pterion is called the Sylvian point. Deep to the pterion lies the stem of the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure) of the brain. The pterion is a clinically important landmark because the middle meningeal artery runs directly beneath it, and injury to this area can cause extradural hemorrhage, which appears as a biconvex opacity on radiological imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ICA Siphon: Incorrect because the internal carotid artery (ICA) siphon is located deeper in the skull, within the cavernous sinus, not directly beneath the pterion.

 

Option C. Wernicke's area: Incorrect because Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus (area 22) of the dominant hemisphere, not directly deep to the pterion.

 

Option D. Pineal gland: Incorrect because the pineal gland is located at the center of the brain in the epithalamus, not related to the pterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H-shaped area on the lateral skull where four bones meet (frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid), and it overlies the stem of the lateral sulcus and middle meningeal artery.

choices.text: Village Health Planning and Management Committee
Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee

questions.text: As part of a health development project in rural India, you're asked about the key community group responsible for overseeing local health, sanitation, and nutrition initiatives. Which committee best fits this description? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee

 

  • One of the key elements of the National Rural Health Mission is the Village Health, Sanitation and Nutrition committee (VHSNC).
  • The committee has been formed to take collective actions on issues related to health and its social determinants at the village level.
  • They are particularly envisaged as being central to ‘local level community action’ under NRHM, which would develop to support the process of Decentralized Health Planning.
  • Thus VHSNC is envisaged to take leadership in providing a platform for improving health awareness and access of community for health services, address specific local needs and serve as a mechanism for community based planning and monitoring.
  • The committee is formed at the revenue village level and it should act as a sub-committee of the Gram Panchayat.
  • It should have a minimum of 15 members which should comprise of elected member of the Panchayat who shall lead the committee, all those working for health and health related services should participate, community members/ beneficiaries and representation from all community sub-groups especially the vulnerable sections and hamlets/ habitations. ASHA residing in the village shall be the member secretary and convener of the committee.

 

 ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES 

 

  • Create awareness about nutritional issues and significance of nutrition as an important determinant of health.
  • Carry out survey on nutritional status and nutritional deficiencies in the village especially among women and children.
  • Identify locally available food stuffs of high nutrient value as well as disseminate and promote best practices (traditional wisdom) congruent with local culture, capabilities and physical environment through a process of community consultation.
  • Inclusion of Nutritional needs in the Village Health Plan – The committee will do an in-depth analysis of causes of malnutrition at the community and household levels, by involving the ANM, AWW, ASHA and ICDS Supervisors.
  • Monitoring and Supervision of Village Health and Nutrition Day to ensure that it is organized every month in the village with the active participation of the whole village.
  • Facilitate early detection of malnourished children in the community; tie up referral to the nearest Nutritional Rehabilitation Centre (NRC) as well as follow up for sustained outcome.
  • Supervise the functioning of Anganwadi Centre (AWC) in the village and facilitate its working in improving nutritional status of women and children.
  • Act as a grievances redressal forum on health and nutrition issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Panchayat Health Committee and Option B. Village Health Planning and Management Committee generally refer to broader terms, but they do not specifically target the integrated approach of the VHSNC.

 

Option C. Rogi Kalyan Samiti (Patient Welfare Committee) / Hospital Management Committee is a simple yet effective management structure. This committee, a registered society, acts as a group of trustees for the hospitals to manage the affairs of the hospital. It consists of members from local Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs), NGOs, local elected representatives and officials from Government sector who are responsible for proper functioning and management of the hospital / Community Health Centre / FRUs. RKS / HMS is free to prescribe, generate and use the funds with it as per its best judgement for smooth functioning and maintaining the quality of services.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The VHSNC plays a crucial role in the grassroots-level health planning and implementation in rural India, ensuring that health initiatives are tailored to the specific needs and conditions of the community.
  • It is a vital part of the health ecosystem, facilitating a comprehensive approach to public health management in rural settings.

questions.text:
How would you manage a child with status epilepticus? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Airway and breathing
  2. IV Lorazepam
  3. Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone
  4. IV Fosphenytoin
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4, 3

 

Status epilepticus is defined as continuous or recurrent seizure activity lasting for more than 5 minutes without regaining consciousness.

 

Status epilepticus is a neurological emergency defined as continuous or recurrent seizure activity lasting for more than 5 minutes without regaining consciousness between episodes. Prompt and systematic management is essential to prevent long-term neurological damage or death.

 

Management Sequence:

 

1. Airway and Breathing: The first priority is to ensure that the airway is open and that the child is breathing adequately. This may involve positioning the child, providing oxygen, and, if necessary, securing the airway with advanced airway management techniques.

 

2. IV Lorazepam: Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the first-line treatment for status epilepticus due to their rapid onset of action and effectiveness in terminating seizures. Lorazepam is typically administered intravenously.

 

4. IV Fosphenytoin: If seizures continue after the administration of a benzodiazepine, IV fosphenytoin (or phenytoin) is used as a second-line agent. It helps to stabilize neuronal membranes and prevent further seizure activity.

 

3. Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone: These agents are used if seizures persist despite initial treatments. Midazolam can be administered intramuscularly or intravenously, while propofol and thiopentone are typically reserved for refractory status epilepticus and may require the child to be in an intensive care setting due to the need for mechanical ventilation and close monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of status epilepticus in children should follow a systematic approach: securing the airway and ensuring breathing, administering a benzodiazepine, followed by fosphenytoin if seizures persist, and considering more potent agents like midazolam, propofol, or thiopentone if the status epilepticus is refractory to initial treatments.

choices.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in physiological jaundice? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

 

In physiological jaundice, there is increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine.

 

Physiological jaundice occurs as a result of increased bilirubin production caused by foetal RB destruction, as well as a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation in the immature neonatal liver. As a result, indirect/unconjugated bilirubin levels would rise. Increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood cause an increase in the production of urobilinogen, which is found in large quantities in the urine. Urine bilirubin is uncommon in this condition.

 

Both physiological jaundice (indirect) and hepatocellular jaundice (direct) can have increased urobilinogen - just through different mechanisms:

  • Physiological: ↑ bilirubin load despite immature conjugation
  • Hepatocellular: ↑ conjugated bilirubin reaching gut despite liver damage


 

 

The following indications are suggestive of pathological jaundice and it warrants further investigations for the cause of jaundice.

 

  1. Jaundice appearing in the first 24-36 hours of birth
  2. A rise in serum bilirubin faster than 5mg/dl/24hr
  3. Serum bilirubin > 12mg/dL in a full-term infant(especially if there are no risk factors)
  4. Serum bilirubin > 10-14mg/dL in a preterm infant
  5. Persistent jaundice after 10-14 days of birth
  6. Direct bilirubin > 2mg/dL at any time

 

If there is persistent indirect hyperbilirubinemia for more than 2 weeks it indicates hemolysis, hereditary glucuronyl transferase deficiency, breastmilk jaundice, hypothyroidism, or intestinal obstruction.

 

When the concentration of unconjugated bilirubin exceeds 20-25mg/dL, bilirubin would penetrate the blood-brain barrier and lead to kernicterus.

 

Phototherapy:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological jaundice is characterized by increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, and the absence of bilirubin in the urine.

questions.text:
Which of the following about the enteric nervous regulation system is false? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Interstitial cells of Cajal are pacemakers
  2. It can function independently of the brain and spinal cord
  3. All the afferents are from the vagus nerve
  4. Myenteric plexus is in the Lamina propria
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

The enteric nervous system (ENS) is often referred to as the "brain of the GIT". This complex network of neurons can function autonomously but also communicates with the central nervous system.

 

3. All the afferents are from the vagus nerve: This is FALSE. While the vagus nerve (parasympathetic) does provide afferent innervation to the GIT, it is not the only source. Both the vagus nerve (parasympathetic) and sympathetic nerves provide afferent innervation to the GIT. 

 

4. Myenteric plexus is in the Lamina propria: This is FALSE. The myenteric plexus (also known as Auerbach's plexus) is located between the longitudinal and circular muscle layers of the muscularis, not in the lamina propria which is part of the mucosa. 

 

Correct statements: 

 

1. Interstitial cells of Cajal are pacemakers: This is TRUE. Interstitial cells of Cajal serve as pacemaker cells in the gastrointestinal tract. They produce Basal Electrical Rhythm (BER), which is defined as cyclic fluctuations in the resting membrane potential ranging from -40 to -60 mV. These cells are critical in establishing the intrinsic electrical rhythmicity of the GIT.

 

2. It can function independently of the brain and spinal cord: This is TRUE. The enteric nervous system is capable of functioning independently of the brain and spinal cord. The enteric nervous system is the "brain of GIT," and enteric nervous system connects with the autonomic nervous system, it can work independently through its own neural circuits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enteric nervous system is anatomically organized into two major plexuses - the myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus located between longitudinal and circular muscle layers that controls motility, and the submucosal (Meissner's) plexus that regulates secretion. The enteric nervous system receives dual innervation from both sympathetic and parasympathetic (vagal) sources while maintaining the ability to function independently.

choices.text: Placenta weight at term is 470 g
Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

questions.text: The following are correct regarding normal placenta, except _______. (INICET NOV 2022) (OBG)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

 

Among the options, Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present (option C) is the incorrect statement.

 

In a normal placenta:

 

  • The placenta at term weighs about 470 g (option A).
  • It is round to oval in shape with a diameter of approximately 22 cm (option B).
  • The central thickness of the placenta is generally greater than 2.5 cm (option D).
  • The umbilical cord in a normal placenta has three vessels—two arteries and one vein. A two-vessel cord is abnormal and can be associated with congenital anomalies.

 

Thus, option C is incorrect because the normal umbilical cord has three vessels, not two.

 

Other Information:

 

The placenta is a discoid, deciduate, and hemochorial structure:

 

  • Deciduate means that the placenta is shed at the time of parturition.
  • Hemochorial indicates that maternal blood comes into direct contact with the fetal trophoblasts.

 

The placenta consists of two plates:

 

  • Chorionic plate: The fetal surface of the placenta, lined by the amniotic membrane, to which the umbilical cord is attached.
  • Basal plate: The maternal side, which is attached to the uterine wall, divided into clefts known as cotyledons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal placenta at term weighs around 470 g, is round-oval with a diameter of 22 cm, and has a three-vessel umbilical cord. A two-vessel cord is an abnormal finding.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male arrives at the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient's vital signs are stable, and a focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) is ordered. Which condition is least likely to be diagnosed using FAST? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retroperitoneal hematoma

 

Detecting retroperitoneal hematoma is challenging with FAST because it is located deep within the abdominal cavity, behind the peritoneum. FAST primarily focuses on the pericardium, pleura, and peritoneum, making it less suitable for detecting retroperitoneal injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pericardial Effusion: FAST is effective at detecting pericardial effusions. It involves examining the pericardial sac for fluid accumulation with probe placed in epigastrium.

 

Option B. Pneumothorax: eFAST can detect pneumothorax to some extent by visualizing the pleural space for the presence of air.

 

Option D. Renal Injury: FAST can detect renal injuries by examining the perinephric space for signs of bleeding or fluid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Among the given options, FAST is the least effective in diagnosing retroperitoneal hematoma due to poor sensitivity of ultrasound for detecting it.
  • CT scan is the preferred diagnostic tool for retroperitoneal injuries, but it should only be performed on hemodynamically stable patients.
  • FAST stands for Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma and is a non-invasive, rapid bedside test used to detect free fluid in the abdomen using sonography.
  • The patient is positioned supine, and a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer is used to scan the subxiphoid, right and left upper quadrants, and suprapubic region to assess potential thoracoabdominal injuries.
  • eFAST is an extended version of FAST that incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: Which marked structure causes lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, along with flexion at the knee joint?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in the image are:

 

Option A. 1- Rectus femoris

Option B. 2- Vastus lateralis

Option C. 3- Adductor longus

Option D. 4- Sartorius

 

Sartorius is involved in lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, and flexion at the knee. The structure marked '4' is sartorius.

 

The sartorius muscle is a long, thin muscle that runs down the front of the thigh. It is the body's longest muscle and is sometimes referred to as the tailor muscle because of the position that tailors often adopt while working. The sartorius muscle originates from the anterior superior iliac spine and the upper half of the notch below it, and runs obliquely across the thigh to insert into the superior aspect of the medial surface of the tibial shaft near the tibial tuberosity. It joins the aponeurosis of the gracilis and semitendinosus muscles to form the pes anserinus.

 

The sartorius muscle is responsible for several actions, including flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the thigh, as well as flexion of the leg. Because of its location and actions, it is involved in many activities that require movement of the lower limb, such as walking, running, and climbing stairs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of the anterior compartment of thigh (spinal segments in bold are the major segments innervating the muscle)

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with progressive loss of peripheral vision in both eyes. She is diagnosed with a pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasma. Which of the following visual field defects is most likely in this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitemporal hemianopia

 

A lesion at the optic chiasma typically causes bitemporal hemianopia, where the patient loses vision in the outer (temporal) fields of both eyes. This occurs because the nasal fibers of the retina, responsible for the temporal visual fields, decussate (cross) at the optic chiasma. Compression of the chiasma, as in pituitary adenomas, interrupts this crossing and results in loss of the outer visual fields of both eyes.

 

Other Options:
