Option A. Central scotoma: This refers to a loss of vision in the central field, usually seen in conditions affecting the optic nerve or macula, such as optic neuritis or macular degeneration.

 

Option B. Bilateral hemianopia: This term is nonspecific but can refer to homonymous hemianopia, a condition where vision is lost in the same side of the visual field in both eyes, usually due to a lesion posterior to the optic chiasma.

 

Option C. Binasal hemianopia: This is a rare visual defect that affects the inner visual fields (nasal fields) and typically occurs with bilateral compression of the optic nerves at the lateral chiasm, not the midline chiasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visual field defects:

questions.text: A patient presented with paradoxical respiration. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. D

 

Explanation:

 

Paradoxical respiration occurs due to the damage of the phrenic nerve, which is marked as D, in the given image.

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

A. Right vagus nerve

B. Left vagus nerve

C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve (inferior laryngeal nerve)

D. Right phrenic nerve

 

 

The phrenic nerve provides motor innervation to the diaphragm, the primary muscle of inspiration. Damage or paralysis of one phrenic nerve can cause one hemidiaphragm to rise during inspiration instead of descending as it normally does, leading to paradoxical movement. This is especially noticeable when the patient is in a supine position. If the right phrenic nerve is affected, the right hemidiaphragm will exhibit this paradoxical movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right vagus nerve: The vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve) has a broad distribution and is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of many organs in the thorax and abdomen. It also provides sensory innervation to the larynx, trachea, esophagus, and a portion of the external ear. It doesn't innervate the diaphragm directly for its motor function.

 

Option B. Left vagus nerve: Similarly to the right vagus, the left vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to many thoracic and abdominal organs but does not control diaphragmatic contractions.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve (inferior laryngeal nerve): This is a branch of the vagus nerve that innervates most intrinsic muscles of the larynx. The recurrent laryngeal nerve is important for vocal cord function. Damage to this nerve can lead to hoarseness or voice changes but does not directly affect respiratory mechanics in the manner described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical movements in the chest are as follows:

 

  • Paradoxical respiration - the aberrant contraction of the abdomen or chest walls, which causes them to move in rather than out during inhalation. It appears in the flail chest.

 

Paradoxical movement of the diaphragm - Normally, during inspiration, the diaphragm descends. Yet, due to diaphragmatic paralysis in phrenic nerve palsy cases, the affected side of the diaphragm moves upward (paradoxical breathing). The gold standard test to find this is to stimulate the phrenic nerve electrically or magnetically while simultaneously recording the transdiaphragmatic pressure and/or the compound muscle action potential. Both fluoroscopy and ultrasonography can show this.

questions.text: A patient was treated with steroids for psoriasis. On stopping the treatment, he develops fever, malaise, and lesions as seen in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pustular psoriasis

 

The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of Pustular psoriasis.

 

Clinical clues for diagnosis of Pustular psoriasis:

 

  • Pustular Lesions seen after withdrawal of corticosteroids in a psoriasis patient
  • History of fever & malaise
  • Presence of pustules on a circumscribed, fiery red & edematous or scaling plaque

 

Acitretin

 

  • Approved for use in the cutaneous manifestations of psoriasis.
  • It is the DOC for Pustular psoriasis.
  • Female patients should avoid conception for 3 years after receiving acitretin treatment to prevent retinoid induced embryopathy.

 

Acitretin:

 

  • Is associated with photosensitivity.
  • It has half-life of 50-70 hours

 

Absolute contraindications:

 

  • Pregnant women
  • Women who are planning to get pregnant
  • Breast-feeding

 

Relative contraindications:

 

  • Leukopenia
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hypercholesterolemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Significant hepatic or renal disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcal infection: While staphylococcal infections can cause skin lesions, there's no direct link provided between steroid withdrawal and the onset of such infections. In fact steroid usage would initiate such staphylococcal infections, not withdrawal.

 

Option C. Acute generalized Exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP): AGEP is typically a reaction to medications not due to steroid withdrawal, and its presentation can be similar to pustular psoriasis.

 

Option D. Sub corneal pustulosis dermatosis: Sub corneal pustular dermatosis is also known as Sneddon-Wilkinson disease. It is a rare condition, characterized by pustules that appear in crops over months or years. However there is no direct link between steroid withdrawal and SCPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient with a history of psoriasis presents with fever, malaise, and widespread pustules following the abrupt withdrawal of systemic corticosteroids, consider pustular psoriasis as the probable diagnosis.
  • This condition can be a severe, life-threatening variant of psoriasis that requires prompt medical attention and management.

 

Ref - Goodman Gillman’s he pharmacological basis of therapeutics – 13th edition page no 1276

Online resources - https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19998529/

Rook’s textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition page no 18.18, 26.22, 35.28, 35.33

questions.text: Criminal responsibility of Insane is defined in: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. McNaughten's Rule

 

“McNaughten’s Rule” also known as “Legal test of insanity”, “right or wrong test” is the legal standard for determining criminal responsibility in cases of insanity.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Curren's rule: of 1964 states that an accused person is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law, as a result of mental disease or defect.

 

Option C. Durham 's rule: of 1954 States that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

 

Option D. American law institute test: (1972) A person is not responsible for the crime, if at the time of committing it, he lacks adequate capacity to appreciate the criminality of his conduct or to adjust it to the requirements of the law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McNaughten's rule is defined by section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC)

 

It states that "A person of unsound mind is not liable for an act."

 

It implies that the defendant was unable to distinguish between right and wrong or otherwise didn't understand what they did because of a "disease of the mind."

questions.text: What is the ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3:1

 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in the blood of a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.

 

Lymphocytes in human circulating blood are approximately 80 to 90 percent T cells, and 10 to 20 percent B cells. The T-cell to B-cell ratio in the normal marrow varies between 4:1 and 5:1, and a significant increase in T-cell numbers was observed in reactive and myelodysplastic states.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.

 

Ratio of CD4 to CD8 T-cells is 2:1.

choices.text: Diffuse type of gastric cancer is characterised by k-RAS mutation
Wnt signaling pathway defect is seen in intestinal-type gastric CA
Depth of cancer has no role in prognosis

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the gastroenterology clinic with complaints of weight loss, early satiety, and anorexia. The physician suspects gastric carcinoma and orders further investigations to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements regarding gastric carcinoma is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Wnt signaling pathway defect is seen in intestinal-type gastric CA.

Gastric carcinoma, or stomach cancer, is a malignant tumor of the stomach lining. Most cases of gastric cancer are sporadic, and only a small percentage are due to genetic predisposition. Lauren's system classifies gastric cancer into two types: Type I - intestinal and Type II - diffuse.

 At the molecular level, the intestinal type of cancer is characterized by mutations in the APC gene or beta-catenin causes increased signalling via the Wnt pathway (Option C).

On the other hand, diffuse-type is characterized by decreased E-cadherin mainly due to loss-of-function mutations in the CDH1 gene (Option B).

Symptoms of both types include nausea, dyspepsia, dysphagia, weight loss, anorexia, early satiety, and anemia.

The most widely used staging system for gastric cancer is TNM, which uses depth of invasion, nodal and distant metastases as prognostic indicators (Option D).

Local invasion into the duodenum, pancreas, and retroperitoneum is common, where chemo or radiation therapy with palliative care is the treatment. When possible, surgery remains the preferred treatment approach.

questions.text: Declaration of Oslo is for? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Therapeutic abortion

 

The Declaration of Oslo was adopted by the World Medical Association (WMA) to address the ethical considerations involved in therapeutic abortion. Therapeutic abortion refers to the termination of pregnancy performed to save the life of the pregnant woman, preserve her physical or mental health, or in cases of severe fetal abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torture: The Declaration of Tokyo is the relevant document that deals with the ethical guidelines for doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment.

 

Option C. Hunger: The Declaration of Malta on Hunger Strikes provides ethical guidelines for physicians concerning the treatment of hunger strikers. This declaration emphasizes the importance of respecting the autonomy of individuals who engage in hunger strikes.

 

Option D. Ethical aspects of medical research: The Declaration of Helsinki is the key document that outlines ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects. It emphasizes the necessity of informed consent, the welfare of research participants, and the importance of conducting research with scientific integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Declaration of Oslo specifically addresses the ethical considerations involved in therapeutic abortion, distinguishing it from other declarations that focus on different ethical issues in medical practice

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NRG-1

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are mesenchymal tumors that commonly present with gastrointestinal bleeding. They are characterized by mutations that lead to the overactivity of tyrosine kinase. The most common mutation associated with GISTs is in the CKIT gene, which leads to the activation of the KIT receptor tyrosine kinase.

 

NRG-1 (Neuregulin 1):

 

NRG-1 is a gene that is part of the epidermal growth factor receptor family. It is not associated with GISTs. Instead, NRG-1 is implicated in the pathogenesis of mental health disorders, such as schizophrenia. Therefore, it is not used as a marker for GISTs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. KIT: KIT mutations are the most common genetic alterations found in GISTs and are critical for the diagnosis and treatment of these tumors.

 

Option B. PDGFR: Mutations in the PDGFR gene occur in a subset of GISTs and play a role similar to KIT mutations in tumor development.

 

Option C. SDH: SDH mutations are linked to Carney-Stratakis syndrome and are significant markers in a subset of GISTs. These mutations lead to defects in cellular respiration and are associated with the development of GISTs and paragangliomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NRG-1 is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors. The primary markers for GISTs include KIT, PDGFR, and SDH mutations.

choices.text: EDV and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in ESV pressure curve
End systolic volume and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in EDV and pressure curve

questions.text:
If the contractility of the heart is decreased, which of the following is seen? (INICET Nov 2021)

 

ESV: End-systolic volume

EDV: End-diastolic volume
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Slope changes in ESV pressure curve

 

A decrease in contractility of the heart can result in changes in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESV pressure curve) in addition to changes in end-systolic volume (ESV) and end-diastolic volume (EDV).

 

When contractility is decreased, the ventricle is less able to generate the same pressure for a given volume of blood, resulting in a reduced slope of the ESV pressure curve. This indicates that the heart is less efficient in ejecting blood during systole.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is B. Slope changes in ESV pressure curve. This is because the slope of the ESV pressure curve is an index of contractility, and a decrease in contractility results in a reduced slope of the curve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. is incorrect because a leftward shift of the end-diastolic pressure-volume curve without a change in slope is seen in conditions such as hypertension and aortic stenosis, where the heart has to generate greater pressure to overcome an increased afterload.

 

Option C. is incorrect because a leftward shift of the end-systolic pressure-volume curve without a change in slope is not typically seen in response to changes in contractility.

 

Option D. is incorrect because a change in the slope of the EDV pressure curve is not typically observed in response to changes in contractility.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A decrease in cardiac contractility leads to a decrease in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume (ESV) curve, indicating reduced efficiency in blood ejection during systole.

questions.text:
True statement regarding the administration of 5 alpha-reductase inhibitors is/are: (INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Reduces dihydrotestosterone levels

 

2. Reduces testosterone levels

 

3. Elevates PSA levels

 

4. Decreases PSA levels
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 4

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors, such as finasteride and dutasteride, are used primarily in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and conditions like male pattern baldness and hirsutism. These medications work by inhibiting the enzyme 5 alpha-reductase, which is responsible for converting testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a more potent androgen.

 

Effects of 5 Alpha-Reductase Inhibitors

 

  1. Reduces Dihydrotestosterone Levels: By inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to DHT, these drugs significantly lower DHT levels in the body. DHT is a key factor in the development and enlargement of the prostate and also contributes to hair loss.
  1. Decreases PSA Levels: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels are often reduced as a result of decreased prostate volume and reduced androgenic stimulation of the prostate. PSA is a marker used to screen for and monitor prostate cancer and other prostate-related conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

  1. Reduces Testosterone Levels: This statement is incorrect. 5 alpha-reductase inhibitors do not significantly reduce testosterone levels. In fact, due to the reduced conversion to DHT, plasma testosterone levels may remain unchanged or even increase slightly.
  2. Elevates PSA Levels: This statement is incorrect. These drugs typically decrease PSA levels due to reduced androgenic activity in the prostate.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Uses: These inhibitors are used alongside surgery and alpha-1 adrenergic blockers for treating BPH. They are also utilized in managing male pattern baldness and hirsutism.
  • Mechanism of Action: By competitively inhibiting 5 alpha-reductase, they reduce the production of DHT, which is responsible for stimulating prostate growth and hair loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors are the competitive inhibitors of the enzyme 5 alpha-reductase which converts testosterone into the more active dihydroxy testosterone (DHT). This enzyme inhibition results in:

 

 

  • Decreased DHT levels
  • Decreased PSA levels
  • Reduces prostate volume
  • However, plasma testosterone levels remain unchanged or may increase due to non-conversion to DHT.

choices.text: To induce anesthesia and relax muscles
To prevent memory loss after the ECT

questions.text: A patient undergoing ECT for his severe depression was given thiopentone and succinylcholine. The purpose of these medications was to? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To induce anesthesia and relax muscles

 

During electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), thiopentone is used to induce anesthesia, ensuring that the patient is unconscious and doesn't experience pain during the procedure. Succinylcholine is a muscle relaxant, used to prevent forceful and uncontrolled muscle contractions that can occur during the ECT, thus reducing the risk of injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To bring calming effect: Neither thiopentone nor succinylcholine is specifically used for their calming effects in the context of ECT.

 

Option B. To produce mood elevation: The medications aren't administered to produce mood elevation. The therapeutic effect of ECT itself is what aids in mood elevation.

 

Option D. To prevent memory loss after the ECT: Memory loss can be a side effect of ECT, but the drugs mentioned are not given to prevent this effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiopentone and succinylcholine are administered prior to ECT to induce anesthesia and relax muscles, respectively, to ensure patient safety and comfort during the procedure.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1069.

questions.text: Identify the lesion as shown in the image below? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neuropathic ulcer

 

  • The provided image indicates the presence of a neuropathic ulcer.

 

Neuropathic ulcers, also known as trophic ulcers, are the result of nerve damage, typically in individuals with conditions like diabetes or peripheral neuropathy. These ulcers are often painless and can develop on the soles of the feet or other areas subject to pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial insufficiency: Arterial insufficiency ulcers are typically caused by poor blood circulation, often due to arterial disease. They often occur on the feet, toes, or lower legs and can appear as painful, pale wounds with well-defined edges. Other signs of ischemia are seen

 

 

Option C. Venous ulcers: Venous ulcers are typically caused by venous insufficiency, which leads to poor blood circulation in the legs. These ulcers often appear near the ankles and are characterized by swelling, redness, and sometimes pain.

 

 

Option D. Tuberculous ulcers: Tuberculous ulcers are a manifestation of tuberculosis infection in the skin. They are characterized by the presence of nodules or ulcers with undermined edges and a necrotic center.

 

 

Tuberculous ulcer with typical bluish undermined margins overlying sternal tuberculosis focus  

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neuropathic ulcers result from peripheral neuropathy, where lack of sensation over pressure points leads to unnoticed minor wounds or cuts, eventually developing into ulcers.
  • Features of neuropathic ulcers include painless, punched out ulcers with regular margins, commonly located on the plantar surface of the foot.
  • Ulcer margins show the presence of calluses.

questions.text: A patient has right upper limb BP of >180/95 mmHg and a left upper limb BP of 130/90 mmHg. He also has early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supravalvular aortic stenosis.

 

An early diastolic murmur in the right 2nd intercostal space is suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Supravalvular aortic stenosis is least likely to be associated with the above findings.

 

BP difference between arms is classical due to blood jet projected towards right brachiocephalic artery, but the murmur of AR is very rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coarctation of the Aorta: Can sometimes show differences in arm blood pressures, especially if the coarctation is proximal to the left subclavian artery. It is also associated with a bicuspid aortic valve, which can lead to AR.

 

Option C. Takayasu Arteritis: Known for causing vascular inflammation leading to stenoses, which can result in differing blood pressures in the arms. About 25% of patients may also have AR.

 

Option D. Aortic Dissection: Typically presents with differential blood pressure between arms and can rapidly lead to AR due to involvement of the aortic root.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While differential arm blood pressure can suggest several cardiovascular anomalies, supravalvular aortic stenosis is least likely among the options given to be associated with these findings, especially concerning the presence of a diastolic murmur indicative of aortic regurgitation.

questions.text: All of the following are major diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal sinusitis except? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive fungal culture

 

A positive fungal culture is a minor diagnostic criterion for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

 

This classification was detailed by Bent and Kuhn, who established criteria based on their findings of several clinical features important for the diagnosis of AFRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of nasal polyps: Polyps are a common and significant finding in AFRS, often contributing to the blockage and symptoms of sinusitis.

 

Option B. Eosinophilic mucin: A hallmark of AFRS, this refers to thick, peanut butter-like mucin with eosinophils.

 

Option C. Characteristic CT findings: These include hyperdense areas within the sinuses, which are indicative of fungal involvement and mucin accumulation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bent and Kuhn described a diagnostic criterion for AFRS. They found 11 important clinical features, 5 of which were termed major criteria and the remaining 6 features as minor criteria. These criteria includes:

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, Volume 1, Page No. 1049

questions.text:
A pediatrician is reviewing mortality trends among children aged between 1-4 years based on verbal autopsy reports from the years 2010-2013. She wants to educate parents on the primary causes of death to improve preventive measures in her community. From the list provided below, which sequence correctly represents the leading causes of death in a descending order for this age group? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Pneumonia
  3. Malaria
  4. Injuries
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 2>1>4>3

 

  • According to the verbal autopsy report of 2010-2013, leading cause of death among 1–4-year-old children in a developing country like India in descending order is Pneumonia > Diarrhea > Injuries > Malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In a developed country, leading causes of death are:

 

  1. Accident injury
  2. Congenital anomaly
  3. Neoplasms
  4. Influenza
  5. Pneumonia

choices.text: Ventricular dysrhythmias are common in children
The no flow phase precedes the period of cardiac arrest in children.
More ventilation to be given compared to chest compressions in children
Dysrhythmias are most often due to respiratory insufficiency in children

questions.text: True regarding the difference between adult and pediatric resuscitation? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dysrhythmias are most often due to respiratory insufficiency in children

 

In pediatric patients, dysrhythmias (abnormal heart rhythms) are more likely to be caused by respiratory insufficiency or hypoxia rather than intrinsic cardiac issues, which are more common causes of dysrhythmias in adults. Hypoxia and respiratory failure are the leading causes of cardiac arrest in children, as their cardiovascular systems are generally healthy compared to adults, where coronary artery disease is more prevalent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventricular dysrhythmias are common in children: Ventricular dysrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation, are relatively uncommon in children. In pediatric patients, the most common dysrhythmias requiring treatment are supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and bradycardia, often secondary to hypoxia or other respiratory issues.

 

Option B. The no-flow phase precedes the period of cardiac arrest in children: The no-flow phase refers to the period between the onset of cardiac arrest and the initiation of effective CPR. While this phase occurs in both adults and children, it does not specifically precede cardiac arrest. The phases of cardiac arrest include the pre-arrest phase, the no-flow phase, the low-flow phase (which begins with CPR), and the post-resuscitation phase (which begins with the return of spontaneous circulation).

 

Option C. More ventilation to be given compared to chest compressions in children: The correct chest compression to ventilation ratio in pediatric CPR is either 30:2 or 15:2, depending on whether one or two rescuers are present. Providing excessive ventilation can decrease venous return, reduce coronary and cerebral blood flow, lower cardiac output, and ultimately decrease the chances of return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC). Therefore, the emphasis is on high-quality chest compressions with appropriate ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pediatric resuscitation, dysrhythmias are most commonly due to respiratory insufficiency or hypoxia, unlike in adults, where intrinsic cardiac causes are more prevalent.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with shortness of breath, bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated and liver was palpable 8 cm below the costal margin. An abnormality in which of the following structures is responsible for the patient's symptoms? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right Ventricle

 

The patient’s presentation is characteristic of right ventricular failure, often secondary to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in chronic smokers.

 

Key clinical features include:

 

  • Shortness of breath: A common symptom in both left and right heart failure but is notably worsened by right heart failure due to fluid overload.
  • Bilateral pitting pedal edema: Indicates fluid retention, a hallmark of right ventricular failure.
  • Abdominal distension: Often due to ascites, which is related to increased venous pressure.
  • Elevated jugular venous pulse (JVP): Reflects increased central venous pressure due to right heart dysfunction.
  • Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver): Due to congestion of blood in the liver secondary to increased venous pressure.

 

Right ventricular failure results from the right ventricle's inability to pump blood effectively to the lungs, leading to a backup of blood in the systemic venous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left Ventricle: Left ventricular failure primarily causes pulmonary congestion and edema due to the backflow of blood into the lungs. Symptoms like shortness of breath would predominate without the systemic venous congestion (e.g., pedal edema, elevated JVP, hepatomegaly) seen in right ventricular failure.

 

Option C. Aorta: An aortic abnormality would not directly cause the combination of symptoms described. Issues with the aorta generally result in systemic hypertension, aortic aneurysm, or dissection, which have different clinical presentations.

 

Option D. Mitral Valve: Mitral valve disease, particularly mitral stenosis or regurgitation, primarily affects the left atrium and ventricle, leading to pulmonary congestion and symptoms more indicative of left heart failure rather than the systemic congestion seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right ventricular failure is characterized by systemic venous congestion, which manifests as elevated jugular venous pressure, pitting pedal edema, hepatomegaly, and abdominal distension. This condition is often seen in chronic smokers due to the impact of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on the heart.

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady came to psychiatry OPD with symptoms of hypomania. There is a past history of maniac episode. Now, she is planning to conceive. Which of the following drug is maximum teratogenic to the fetus?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Valproate

 

  • Valproate is the most teratogenic drug among the drugs used in bipolar disorder and anti-epileptic medications. It causes congenital anomalies like neural tube defects (spina bifida), cleft lip and cleft palate, and cardiac anomalies. It also contributes to poor cognitive development in children.
  • Although lithium is also teratogenic and can cause Ebstein anomaly in the fetus, but it is less teratogenic than valproate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: This medication is also used to treat bipolar disorder and epilepsy, but it has a lower risk of teratogenic effects compared to valproate. The risk of major congenital malformations with lamotrigine is relatively low.

 

Option C. Oxcarbazepine: Used to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder, oxcarbazepine has a moderate risk of teratogenic effects, but it is still considered less teratogenic than valproate.

 

Option D. Olanzapine: This antipsychotic medication is used for bipolar disorder and schizophrenia. While there are some risks associated with its use during pregnancy, including potential metabolic complications, it is not considered as teratogenic as valproate.

 

Additional Note on Lithium

 

Although lithium is also used to treat bipolar disorder and is known to be teratogenic, causing conditions like Ebstein's anomaly (a heart defect), its teratogenic risk is considered lower than that of valproate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Valproate is the most teratogenic drug among the options listed, causing significant congenital anomalies such as neural tube defects, cleft lip and palate, and cardiac anomalies, as well as poor cognitive development. It should be avoided in women who are planning to conceive or are pregnant.

choices.text: Normal anion gap, metabolic acidosis
High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis
High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A patient with renal failure develops vomiting in ICU. ABG analysis showed pH - 7.4, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L, HC03- = 24mEq/L, PaC02 = 40 mmHg. What is the likely metabolic abnormality? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

 

Clinical history of renal failure should hint towards possibility of preexisting metabolic acidosis. Important in MCQs to always calculate AG even if ABG appears normal.

 

AG: 145-(100+24) = 21 (Normal ~12)

 

Excess unmeasured anion(H) combines with HCO3 thereby reducing the HCO3 proportionately.

 

Hence Delta ratio i.e., ΔAG(AG-12) /ΔHCO3(24-HCO3) = >2.

 

Value >2 indicate coexisting Metabolic alkalosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal ABG: The pH is indeed normal, but the underlying disturbances (as reflected by an increased anion gap) indicate that the system is not normal.

 

Option B. Normal anion gap, metabolic acidosis: The anion gap is increased, ruling out normal anion gap acidosis.

 

Option D. High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis: This choice incorrectly identifies the nature of acid-base disturbances, confusing the interpretation and relationship between anion gap and bicarbonate levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with renal failure and symptoms like vomiting, it's crucial to evaluate both the anion gap and changes in bicarbonate to identify complex acid-base disturbances such as the coexistence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Middle meningeal artery

 

Explanation:

 

The middle meningeal artery (MMA) is a branch of the maxillary artery (a terminal branch of the external carotid artery). The MMA enters the middle cranial fossa by passing through the foramen spinosum. After entering the skull, it courses laterally to the pterion.

 

Given the proximity of the MMA to the pterion, trauma to this region can lead to an extradural (epidural) hematoma if the MMA is torn. This is because the MMA runs just deep to the pterion, between the skull and the dura mater.

 

This makes the MMA the artery most closely related to the pterion, and a fracture at the pterion can lead to rupture of this artery.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal carotid artery:

 

  • The internal carotid artery (ICA) is a major artery that supplies blood to the brain. It arises from the common carotid artery and enters the cranial cavity through the carotid canal.
  • While the ICA does travel inside the skull and provides blood to the brain, it doesn't have a direct relationship with the pterion. It is more medial in its course.

 

Option C. Anterior cerebral artery:

 

  • The anterior cerebral artery is one of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. It supplies the medial and superior parts of the brain.
  • Though it's an essential artery for cerebral circulation, it doesn't have a direct relationship with the pterion, as its course and distribution are more medial.

 

Option D. Deep temporal artery:

 

  • The deep temporal arteries are branches of the maxillary artery that ascend between the temporalis muscle and the side of the skull.
  • They supply the temporalis muscle, and while they are in the vicinity of the pterion, they are not as closely related as the middle meningeal artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone.

 

Given that it rests across the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere, it is a significant structure. Since the bone in this region is fragile, any injury could cause the middle meningeal artery to burst, resulting in an extradural hematoma.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is not involved in Th1 response? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IL- 4

 

The cytokine not involved in TH1 response is IL-4.

 

T-cell response in this early stage is dominated by TH1 cells that produce IFN-γ, which stimulates macrophages to secrete high levels of the cytokines TNF, IL-1, and IL-6 that cause fever.

 

IL-12 is secreted by macrophages and promotes the proliferation of TH1 cells.

 

The 1 cells secrete IL-2 which activates natural killer cells (NK cells) and cytotoxic T cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IFN-γ (Interferon-gamma): IFN-γ (Interferon-gamma) is a key cytokine produced by Th1 cells. It activates macrophages and enhances their ability to destroy ingested microbes, and it also promotes the production of IgG antibodies that are essential for opsonization and phagocytosis of pathogens.

 

Option B. IL-2 (Interleukin-2): IL-2 (Interleukin-2) is produced by Th1 cells and plays a critical role in the activation and proliferation of T cells, including natural killer (NK) cells and cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs), which are crucial for the immune response against intracellular pathogens.

 

Option C. IL-12 (Interleukin-12): IL-12 (Interleukin-12) is produced by antigen-presenting cells (like dendritic cells and macrophages) and is essential for the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells. It also stimulates the production of IFN-γ by these Th1 cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigation is used for a definitive diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Globin gene sequencing

 

Based on the clinical presentation of low hemoglobin levels, the presence of target cells in the blood smear, and the need for repeated blood transfusions, the most likely diagnosis is thalassemia. Thalassemia is an inherited disorder affecting the production of alpha- or beta-globin chains, leading to an imbalance in globin chain synthesis. This imbalance results in ineffective erythropoiesis and hemolysis, requiring frequent blood transfusions.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thalassemia: A genetic disorder that can be categorized into alpha-thalassemia and beta-thalassemia based on the affected globin chain. The severity of the condition depends on the number of functioning globin genes.
  • Definitive Diagnosis: The definitive diagnosis of thalassemia is made through globin gene sequencing, which identifies mutations in the genes encoding the globin chains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC): HPLC is used as a screening tool for thalassemia and other hemoglobinopathies by analyzing hemoglobin fractions. However, it is not definitive for diagnosing thalassemia.

 

Option B. Ferritin levels estimation: Ferritin levels are used to assess iron stores in the body, particularly in cases of iron deficiency anemia or iron overload. It is not diagnostic for thalassemia.

 

Option C. Bone marrow aspiration: While bone marrow aspiration can reveal ineffective erythropoiesis and hypercellularity, it is not used for a definitive diagnosis of thalassemia.

 

Hemoglobin Patterns:

 

  • Normal Hemoglobin Pattern: HbA = 95%, HbA2 = 3.5%, HbF = 1.5%
  • Beta-thalassemia Trait: HbA = 90%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 5%
  • Beta-thalassemia Intermedia: HbA = 45%, HbA2 = 5%, HbF = 50%

 

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis is another tool used for screening, often complemented by HPLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Globin gene sequencing is the definitive test for diagnosing thalassemia, a genetic disorder affecting hemoglobin production.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding Haab's Striae?

 

  1. Not seen in juvenile glaucoma
  2. Usually horizontal or concentric to the limbus
  3. Are usually indistinguishable from birth trauma striae
  4. Persist even after control of glaucoma
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 & 4 are correct

 

Haab's striae are characterized by breaks in Descemet's membrane, often presenting as double "tram-track" lines that are concentric to the limbus. These are typically associated with congenital glaucoma (Buphthalmos) and are not commonly seen in juvenile glaucoma. Haab's striae tend to be horizontal or concentric around the limbus, making them distinct from birth trauma striae, which are often oblique or vertical. Additionally, Haab's striae usually remain visible even after glaucoma has been managed or controlled.

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option 3: Incorrect because Haab's striae are distinguishable from birth trauma striae due to their characteristic concentric pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haab's striae are breaks in Descemet's membrane commonly seen in congenital glaucoma, characterized by horizontal or concentric lines around the limbus, and persist even after glaucoma management.

questions.text: A child presents with bilateral proptosis. Which investigation will help you in arriving at a diagnosis of chloroma? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Peripheral smear

 

Chloroma or granulocytic sarcoma is an extramedullary manifestation of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It is a localized tumor forming mass occurring in the skin or orbit due to local infiltration of the tissues by leukemic cells. The tumor is greenish in appearance due to the presence of myeloperoxidase.

 

The diagnosis of AML is made by a combination of routine blood picture and bone marrow examination, coupled with cytochemical stains and other special laboratory investigations.

 

The best investigation among the given options would be a peripheral blood smear which shows the following-

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelets: While platelet count can be abnormal in AML, it is not the primary diagnostic tool for chloroma.

 

Option C. Hb concentration: Hemoglobin concentration might be reduced in AML due to anemia, but it is not specific for diagnosing chloroma.

 

Option D. Leucocytic count: Leukocyte count can be elevated, normal, or low in AML, but it does not specifically help diagnose chloroma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The peripheral blood smear is the key investigation to diagnose chloroma, revealing the presence of myeloblasts, which are indicative of acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortan pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, page no - 1154

choices.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN
Arterial internal elastic lamina defect

questions.text: Berry aneurysm occurs due to? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial internal elastic lamina defect

 

Berry aneurysm occurs due an arterial internal elastic lamina defect.

 

Berry (Saccular) aneurysms occur when there is collagen deficiency in the internal elastic lamina and breakdown of the tunica media. An outpouching, consisting of only tunica intima and adventitia, protrudes through the defect in the internal elastic lamina and tunica media to produce the aneurismal sac

 

As an aneurysm develops, it typically forms a neck with a dome and the arterial internal elastic lamina disappears at the base of the neck. The media thins and connective tissue replaces the smooth-muscle cells. The site of rupture is most often the dome. Here the wall thins, and the tear that allows bleeding is usually ≤0.5 mm long.

 

The most frequent cause of clinically significant subarachnoid hemorrhage is rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm.

 

Saccular/ Berry aneurysm is the most common type of intracranial aneurysm. About 90% of saccular aneurysms are found near major arterial branch points in the anterior circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN: While hypertension (HTN) is a risk factor that can exacerbate the progression of an aneurysm, it is not the primary cause of Berry aneurysm formation. The initial defect occurs in the internal elastic lamina.

 

Option C. Endothelial layer defect: The endothelial layer is the innermost lining of blood vessels, but defects in this layer alone do not cause Berry aneurysms. The structural weakness in Berry aneurysms is primarily related to the internal elastic lamina and the underlying media.

 

Option D. Adventitia defect: The adventitia is the outermost layer of the blood vessel, but defects in the adventitia alone are not responsible for the formation of Berry aneurysms. The crucial defect is in the internal elastic lamina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Berry aneurysms occur due to a defect in the arterial internal elastic lamina, leading to a weakened vessel wall and the potential for aneurysmal outpouching and rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following test is used for antibiotic sensitivity? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E-test (Epsilometer test)

 

The E-test or Epsilometer test is specifically designed for antibiotic sensitivity testing. It involves:

 

  • Using a Muller-Hinton agar (MHA) plate as the culture medium
  • Streaking the test organism on the plate
  • Applying an E-strip containing gradients of antibiotic concentrations
  • The strip has increasing antibiotic concentration going up and decreasing concentration going down
  • Where the zone of inhibition intersects the strip indicates the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) of the antibiotic
  • Formation of an elliptical zone of inhibition around the strip indicates susceptibility

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elek's test

 

  • This is used for detecting diphtheria toxin production by Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • It's a gel precipitation test where antitoxin strips are used to detect toxin production
  • Not related to antibiotic sensitivity testing

 

Option C. Latex agglutination test

 

  • This is an agglutination-based test used for various diagnostic purposes
  • Used for detecting antigens or antibodies in clinical specimens
  • Not used for determining antibiotic sensitivity

 

Option D. CAMP test

 

  • Used to detect beta-hemolysis
  • Primarily used for identifying Group B Streptococcus (S. agalactiae) and Listeria
  • Not related to antibiotic susceptibility testing

 

Educational Objective:

 

The E-test (Epsilometer test) is the standard method for determining the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) of antibiotics against bacteria using an antibiotic gradient strip.

questions.text: What is the root value of cremasteric reflex? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. L1, L2

 

Explanation:

 

The cremasteric reflex is mediated through the sensory fibers of the ilioinguinal nerve (L1) and the motor fibers of the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2). When the inner thigh is stroked, sensory impulses travel via the ilioinguinal nerve to the spinal cord segments L1 and L2, and motor impulses from these segments, through the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve, cause the cremaster muscle to contract, pulling the testicles upward.

 

The cremasteric reflex's afferent and efferent branches:

 

  • Afferent - Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Efferent - Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T8, T9: These thoracic spinal nerve roots primarily innervate the muscles and skin of the thoracic region and contribute to the intercostal nerves. They are not involved in the cremasteric reflex.

 

Option C. L3, L4: These lumbar spinal nerve roots are primarily associated with the front of the thigh and the medial side of the leg and foot. The femoral nerve, which is the largest nerve arising from the lumbar plexus, is derived from these roots. These roots are not directly involved in the cremasteric reflex but are important for the patellar (knee-jerk) reflex.

 

Option D. S1, S2: These sacral spinal nerve roots play a major role in innervating the posterior thigh, most of the leg and foot, and the perineum. They contribute to the sciatic nerve, among others. Reflexes like the ankle jerk (Achilles reflex) involve these nerve roots. They are not associated with the cremasteric reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cremasteric reflex is mediated by L1 and L2. In this reflex, there is ipsilateral elevation of the testicle following stroking of the medial thigh.

 

Other clinical reflexes and their root values: -

 

Achilles reflex – S1, S2

Patellar reflex – L3, L4

Biceps and brachio-radialis reflexes – C5, C6

Triceps reflex – C7, C8

Anal wink reflex – S3, S4

Abdominal reflex – T7 – T12

questions.text: Which of the following viruses spreads predominantly through water? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HAV (Hepatitis A Virus)

 

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) primarily spreads through the fecal-oral route and contaminated water. It is one of the main viral pathogens that uses water as its predominant transmission route. The virus is highly stable in water and sewage, making waterborne transmission a significant public health concern, especially in areas with poor sanitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HCV (Hepatitis C Virus): Incorrect because HCV spreads predominantly through the parenteral route, particularly through needlestick injuries, blood transfusions, and surgical procedures.

 

Option C. HDV (Hepatitis D Virus): Incorrect because HDV is a dependent virus that requires the presence of HBV for its replication and transmission. It cannot spread independently through water.

 

Option D. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus): Incorrect because HBV primarily spreads through vertical transmission (mother to child) in developing countries like India. While sexual transmission is possible, it's relatively rare. It does not spread through water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis A virus spreads predominantly through the fecal-oral route and contaminated water, unlike other hepatitis viruses, which have different primary modes of transmission.
